item.description:
Code you didn't write in a program that hasn't been touched in a decade is soon to misbehave in ways far removed from obvious symptoms

Cool https://t.co/jlkMkTk7K8
item.source:markdown:
Code you didn't write in a program that hasn't been touched in a decade is soon to misbehave in ways far removed from obvious symptoms

item.title: GenerativeArt interlude
item.description:
Extended music flowers

Same as the basic music flowers, except now spreading the measures across the page instead of overlaying them

You can really see more of the structure of the music

Mozart String Quartet No. 3 in G Major, K. 156 (2nd movement) https://t.co/6vHoOD6dgr

Something interesting happening in the back half of these measures

Schubert String Quartet No. 10 in E-flat Major, Opus 124, No. 1 (4th movement) https://t.co/6e411HHqr0

Intricate patterning

Schumann Quartet in a minor, op. 41, no. 1 (4th movement) https://t.co/rDErS8kEzw

Last one, a little hard to see because there are so many parts but I like how you see the structure of the music here anyway

Di Rocco Missa in Honorem papae Benedicti (Gloria) https://t.co/j1sVA9bCZi

Decoder ring reminder: Each row is a part Each rosette is a measure Colour = note (e.g. A, B) Angle = start + duration within measure Distance from center = pitch relative to lowest octave Distance across canvas = measure
item.source:markdown:
Extended music flowers
Same as the basic music flowers, except now spreading the measures across the page instead of overlaying them
You can really see more of the structure of the music
Mozart String Quartet No. 3 in G Major, K. 156 (2nd movement) https://t.co/6vHoOD6dgr
Something interesting happening in the back half of these measures
Schubert String Quartet No. 10 in E-flat Major, Opus 124, No. 1 (4th movement) https://t.co/6e411HHqr0
Intricate patterning
Schumann Quartet in a minor, op. 41, no. 1 (4th movement) https://t.co/rDErS8kEzw
Last one, a little hard to see because there are so many parts but I like how you see the structure of the music here anyway
Di Rocco Missa in Honorem papae Benedicti (Gloria) https://t.co/j1sVA9bCZi
Decoder ring reminder: Each row is a part Each rosette is a measure Colour = note (e.g. A, B) Angle = start + duration within measure Distance from center = pitch relative to lowest octave Distance across canvas = measure

item.title: GenerativeArt interlude
item.description:
Music flowers

Each flower is a part. Measures are overlaid so you can see the patterning of time. Colour is the note (A, B, C, etc.), distance is relative pitch.

Ludwig van Beethoven Große Fuge in B flat major Opus 133 https://t.co/1xKynqkpch

Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart: String Quarter No. 1 in G Major (3rd movement)

Mozart, my man, all those measures empty for the final beat https://t.co/0JsrDdjnEO

Johann Sebastian Bach Brandenburg Concerto No 2. in F Major (1st movement)

Bach likes to fill things in densely, but keeps the lower octaves to separate parts (note the holes at the center for most of the parts and the elaborate symmetric patterns) https://t.co/lLCXGMu5oM
item.source:markdown:

Each flower is a part. Measures are overlaid so you can see the patterning of time. Colour is the note (A, B, C, etc.), distance is relative pitch.

item.description: @line_o @barefootliam I think it all depends on what you're using the random number generator for Making randomized art or fuzz testing isn't the same as trying to create realistic simulations of physical processes
item.source:markdown: @line_o @barefootliam I think it all depends on what you're using the random number generator for Making randomized art or fuzz testing isn't the same as trying to create realistic simulations of physical processes

item.description: @barefootliam Absolutely Just a reminder to pick the right tool for the job It's easy to get a little complacent
Pseudo random number generators, not as good as you might hope https://t.co/ID8RyEqse1
item.source:markdown: Pseudo random number generators, not as good as you might hope https://t.co/ID8RyEqse1

item.title: GenerativeArt interlude
item.description:
Patterns of music

Beethoven Große Fuge in B flat major Opus 133

Dig that dramatic pause in the lower registers

#XQuery #SVG https://t.co/6MUNpyUveA

Take a MusicXML score.

Map parts to colour gradients (specific notes to hues within that gradient), pitch to height from baseline, duration as line length.

Then wrap the whole thing along a curve.

Johannes Brahms String Quarter in C minor, Op. 51 no. 1 (second movement) https://t.co/jUc8UOXuSF

Mapping to smooth edges along curls that increase and decrease in size.

Johann Sebastian Bach Brandenburg Concerto No 2. in F Major (second movement) https://t.co/0kYdewFCcc

I like the idea of music as a pattern sequence generator, I'll probably experiment with using it that was rather than this rather direct rendering

Shout out to Project Gutenberg, where I sourced the MusicXML
item.source:markdown:
Patterns of music
Beethoven Große Fuge in B flat major Opus 133
Dig that dramatic pause in the lower registers
#XQuery #SVG https://t.co/6MUNpyUveA
Take a MusicXML score.
Map parts to colour gradients (specific notes to hues within that gradient), pitch to height from baseline, duration as line length.
Then wrap the whole thing along a curve.
Johannes Brahms String Quarter in C minor, Op. 51 no. 1 (second movement) https://t.co/jUc8UOXuSF
Mapping to smooth edges along curls that increase and decrease in size.
Johann Sebastian Bach Brandenburg Concerto No 2. in F Major (second movement) https://t.co/0kYdewFCcc
I like the idea of music as a pattern sequence generator, I'll probably experiment with using it that was rather than this rather direct rendering
Shout out to Project Gutenberg, where I sourced the MusicXML

item.title: GenerativeArt interlude

Early on in the development of the blobs (previous thread), things were wonky, but the debugging marks looked kinda cool, so circling back to run with that, adding a little texture, etc.

#XQuery #SVG https://t.co/xMI4OR2ket

Art: where bugs are opportunities https://t.co/tEhfpLrTQ9

item.title: GenerativeArt interlude
item.description:
Blobs

#XQuery #SVG https://t.co/fjMy1doX3S

The dragonfly

The number and closeness of the echoing layers is randomized https://t.co/ftSnWDiuYb

Santorini

Using a randomized colour scheme instead of a sequential one https://t.co/EYXycMT2uV

The butterfly

The basic process here is to take an arrangement of points, and smoothly connect circular arcs between near neighbours. Hilarity ensues. https://t.co/3lCtRwvmC4

Like Rorschach blots, you see what you see, I suppose.

Leafy sea dragon? Illuminated capital? New hill-top subdivision? https://t.co/LpOWAKS88Z
item.source:markdown:
Blobs
#XQuery #SVG https://t.co/fjMy1doX3S

The basic process here is to take an arrangement of points, and smoothly connect circular arcs between near neighbours. Hilarity ensues. https://t.co/3lCtRwvmC4
Like Rorschach blots, you see what you see, I suppose.

item.description:
@msokolov @barefootliam @kurt_cagle Stemming Arabic, where there are No Good Answers

Precision? You want precision? Hah hah hah hah hah

Oh, recall? GTFO

@barefootliam @kurt_cagle Punctuational exceptions and compound weirdness

don't aujourd'hui d'accord entr'acte

These bastards

running runnings

Also: all designers of stem algorithms ARE mad as hatters BWA HAH HAH
item.source:markdown:
@barefootliam @kurt_cagle Punctuational exceptions and compound weirdness
don't aujourd'hui d'accord entr'acte
These bastards
running runnings
Also: all designers of stem algorithms ARE mad as hatters BWA HAH HAH

item.title: GenerativeArt interlude
item.description:
A river runs through it

Showing the height field: Each triangular face is shaded with a diffuse lighting model based on dot products of the face normal & the direction of illumination (where is the sun? exercise for viewer)

#XQuery #SVG https://t.co/FxhycogByH

The Cordillera

When we don't do a lot of pruning of side branches... https://t.co/dNVrEvgD4i

We can use a more boring height field. Previous ones use ridged fractal noise; here we use a single staight ridge line. Not so naturalistic, but interesting in its own way. https://t.co/ZNj9R10efJ

Rivers made by joining points in a hex grid, computing splines off joined channels for smoothing, w/ some pruning. To avoid straight lines, the actual point locations in the grid are jostled a bit. But... we can jostle them more, applying point-to-point function

A little warped https://t.co/HPBCxjBvsj

Lava cracks in the asteroid as it crashes into the atmosphere https://t.co/j62E1fIlW4

Mess with things enough, and it looks like alien cave art https://t.co/iBirIRsw4O
item.source:markdown:
A river runs through it
Showing the height field: Each triangular face is shaded with a diffuse lighting model based on dot products of the face normal & the direction of illumination (where is the sun? exercise for viewer)
#XQuery #SVG https://t.co/FxhycogByH
The Cordillera
When we don't do a lot of pruning of side branches... https://t.co/dNVrEvgD4i
We can use a more boring height field. Previous ones use ridged fractal noise; here we use a single staight ridge line. Not so naturalistic, but interesting in its own way. https://t.co/ZNj9R10efJ
Rivers made by joining points in a hex grid, computing splines off joined channels for smoothing, w/ some pruning. To avoid straight lines, the actual point locations in the grid are jostled a bit. But... we can jostle them more, applying point-to-point function
A little warped https://t.co/HPBCxjBvsj
Lava cracks in the asteroid as it crashes into the atmosphere https://t.co/j62E1fIlW4
Mess with things enough, and it looks like alien cave art https://t.co/iBirIRsw4O

item.description:
@iamscicomm Practice the $!*? out of my talk. By the time I do it for real, I've practiced it scores of times.

Also: put a "Stop. Breathe." in my notes pages.

item.description:
Thus endeth my live-tweeting of #balisage2022

Non-markup followers, thank you for your patience

We return to normal service
item.source:markdown:
Thus endeth my live-tweeting of #balisage2022
Non-markup followers, thank you for your patience
We return to normal service

item.description:
Excel to Excel using XML, really? (LB) Geert Bormans #balisage2022

GB: Context: Excel pollution reports, want to merge/transform

Really wanted a bit more [shock!] validation/correction; early feedback on quality of data, as report

#balisage2022

GB: 3 object types, 2000 sites, >2000 installations, 200 installation parts #balisage2022

GB: Code mapping (value to code, value to concept URI), 50-100 cross-object conditional mapping

#balisage2022

GB: Dump everything into 100MB XML file QA errors: 10000+ error messages on first iterations #balisage2022

GB: In the end: XProc 3 pipeline Practice is to save whole folder (including code) into SVN so have data in branch after each run Convert early on to semantic XML so good for comparison #balisage2022

GB: Rule based (Schematron) quality report, able to filter out and sort based on rules they care about #balisage2022

GB: (Shows example) #balisage2022

GB: Just getting table out of Excel one sheet at a time #balisage2022

GB: Excel XML format is complex, can be daunting, but allows us to do what we want to do #balisage2022

GB: (Showing details of pipeline) #balisage2022

GB: XML stack -- a good choice? Yes. Would have been a lot more work. #balisage2022

GB: Rules-based approach (XSLT, Schematron) enabled quick updates based on early feedback #balisage2022
item.source:markdown:
Excel to Excel using XML, really? (LB) Geert Bormans #balisage2022
GB: Context: Excel pollution reports, want to merge/transform
Really wanted a bit more [shock!] validation/correction; early feedback on quality of data, as report
#balisage2022
GB: 3 object types, 2000 sites, >2000 installations, 200 installation parts #balisage2022
GB: Code mapping (value to code, value to concept URI), 50-100 cross-object conditional mapping
#balisage2022
GB: Dump everything into 100MB XML file QA errors: 10000+ error messages on first iterations #balisage2022
GB: In the end: XProc 3 pipeline Practice is to save whole folder (including code) into SVN so have data in branch after each run Convert early on to semantic XML so good for comparison #balisage2022
GB: Rule based (Schematron) quality report, able to filter out and sort based on rules they care about #balisage2022
GB: (Shows example) #balisage2022
GB: Just getting table out of Excel one sheet at a time #balisage2022
GB: Excel XML format is complex, can be daunting, but allows us to do what we want to do #balisage2022
GB: (Showing details of pipeline) #balisage2022
GB: XML stack -- a good choice? Yes. Would have been a lot more work. #balisage2022
GB: Rules-based approach (XSLT, Schematron) enabled quick updates based on early feedback #balisage2022
